Dear Ms. Klinski:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

III. METHODOLOGY

ALLEGATION:
Youth reported being inappropriately touched by staff. No specific details or date,
other than October, were provided.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was reported to Centralized Intake and transferred for investigation.
The youth involved is over 18 years old. The allegations noted the following,
This was reported by the Director to Centralized Intake yesterday but not opened
because the youth is 18 years old. It was reportedly sent to Adult Protective
Services. Law enforcement was also notified by the facility. Lincoln Center youth,
Youth A, reported that he was touched inappropriately by Staff 1. No specific
details or date, other than October, were provided.
I met with the Director at the facility on 11/24/21 and he noted that he reported the
incident to Centralized Intake and local law enforcement on 11/23/21. The Director
said that this information was not brought to his attention by staff, but when Youth A
was interviewed by a DHHS PREA Juvenile Compliance Analyst he reported the
allegation, and the Analyst advised the Director. The Director said that he often talks
to Youth A who had not mentioned this allegation. Law enforcement was already out
to the facility and interviewed Youth A, Staff 1, and the Facility Manager on 11/23/21.
The Director implemented a safety plan for Staff 1 to be removed from Youth A’s
pod and reassigned so they will have no contact until the investigation is over. The
Director also provided documentation related to the incident.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 11/24/21. Youth A reported that he told his
Therapist about the allegation in October and gave her a written statement. Youth A
said the Therapist didn’t do anything with the statement other than process his
consequences because he had acted out. Youth A said he didn’t care about what
Staff 1 did and would not report any details as to what occurred. Youth A was upset
because there was an incident that occurred where he and Staff 1 were arguing over
some chips and Youth A said that he and Staff 1 said things they shouldn’t have but
Youth A would not provide specific details. Youth A said three peers were present
but don’t know much and didn’t see much. Youth A said that his peers signed his
written statement because of the consequences he received after the argument.
I interviewed the Therapist at the facility on 11/24/21. The Therapist said that she
was not here during the incident with Youth A and Staff 1 when they got into the
argument. From what the Therapist said she learned afterward, Youth A asked for
chips but had already had some and then got escalated and began arguing with
Staff 1. The Therapist said that it appeared both Youth A and Staff 1 said some
things they shouldn’t have which included Youth A threatening to bring his family up
to assault Staff 1. The Therapist said that Youth A wrote a petition and had his group
members sign it. In this written petition, Youth A stated that Staff 1 had touched him
inappropriately but did not say when this happened. The Therapist said she asked
Youth A, but he did not give details or say when this happened. The Therapist said
3

she took this as Youth A receiving a consequence for his behavior, so he was
retaliating on Staff 1 and trying to get her fired. The Therapist said that she got the
Supervisor and Staff 2 to meet with Youth A and process the situation, but they did
not get clarity on what Youth A was alleging occurred with Staff 1 touching him.
When asked about this allegation being reported to Centralized Intake, the Therapist
said that she told the Supervisor as well as an Intern working with the Clinical
Director and documented it in a clinical note. The Therapist said she only makes a
report if she is told to do so. When reminded that the Therapist is a mandated
reporter, the Therapist appeared to know this as she understood that she would
have to make a report if a youth disclosed or alleged abuse by a parent. I clarified for
the Therapist that the requirement to report is the same and that telling a supervisor
or other facility staff does not relieve her of her obligation to report the allegation to
Centralized Intake.
I interviewed Youths B, C, and D at the facility on 11/24/21. All of these youth were
in the dining area when the altercation between Youth A and Staff 1 occurred and
said they heard Youth A call Staff 1 a predator. None of these youth reported
knowing any specifics as to what Youth A was alleging Staff 1 had done to him.
None of the youth reported ever seeing Staff 1 act or touch Youth A inappropriately.
None reported Staff 1 being inappropriate with them. The three youths said that they
signed Youth A’s written statement as they felt Youth A got unduly consequented
because of the verbal altercation with Staff 1. The youth said Staff 1 was also
arguing with Youth A and being confrontational so they felt Youth A shouldn’t be the
only one getting in trouble.
On 11/29/21, Youth A’s placing worker emailed that she had met with Youth A, but
he did not provide any clarifying information related to the allegations.
I interviewed the Facility Manager (FM) on 12/01/21. The FM said that he was on
duty and was aware that Staff 1 and Youth A exchanged words over some chips
because Youth A said he didn’t get any extra chips. The FM said he reviewed video
and Youth A had received extra chips. The FM said that Youth A called Staff 1
names and called her a predator but did not say anything that Staff 1 had done and
did not make an actual complaint or allegation at that time. The FM said that the next
day the Therapist and Supervisor addressed Youth A with his group. The FM said
Youth A was trying to get his peers to back up his argument so he would not lose a
level and, in that process, said that Staff 1 touches kids. Youth A had also put that
Staff 1 touched him in the written statement, but when asked about this, Youth A did
not give any details. The FM said that Youth A’s goal was to get the write-up for his
misbehavior to disappear.
I interviewed the Supervisor on 12/01/21, at the facility. The Supervisor said that this
incident started in the dining hall when Youth A claimed he didn’t get extra chips, but
he had. Words were exchanged between Youth A and Staff 1 and Youth A got
escalated. The Supervisor said he heard the argument from the hall and went to talk
to Youth A. The Supervisor said that Youth A made no comments to him about Staff
4

1 touching kids. The Supervisor said that the following day, Youth A wrote a letter
saying that Staff 1 touched him inappropriately and gave it to the Therapist. The
Therapist and Supervisor met with Youth A and Youth A didn’t provide any specifics
to the allegation. The Supervisor said that there were “holes in his story.” The
Supervisor also stated that the Therapist felt Youth A was lying about the allegation.
When asked about why the Supervisor did not ensure this allegation was reported to
Centralized Intake, he said he did not report it because the Therapist had the letter
and he thought she had reported it. I clarified for the Supervisor that the requirement
to report is not lifted because he thought someone else reported and also noted that
it is his obligation to ensure allegations are reported to Centralized Intake so that
they may be investigated.
On 12/03/21, Youth A’s placing worker emailed the following after meeting with
Youth A again,
Youth A was vague and the writer asked for specific communication about what
he meant with "touched inappropriately?" Youth A stated that his genitals were
touched "groped" by staff that was not perceived to be an accident. Youth stated
that he happened more than 2 times and less than 5 times. Youth A stated that
he also spoke with the Police about it following our meeting last week (on
11/23/21).
I interviewed Staff 1 at the facility, on 12/09/21. Staff 1 reported that she never
touched Youth A or any residents inappropriately. Staff 1 said that Youth A was mad
because he couldn’t go to the gym, wasn’t following directives and then got mad
over some chips. Staff 1 said she doesn’t work with Youth A often and noted only a
handful of times that she’s been on his pod. Staff 1 said that during the incident
related to the chips she reminded Youth A of the rules, policies, and set boundaries.
Staff 1 denied saying anything about Youth A or his family. Staff 1 said that she is
now on another pod on midnight shift.
I interviewed Staff 2 at the facility on 12/09/21. Staff 2 reported that she was not here
on the day of the incident with Staff 1 and Youth A. The following day Staff 2 said
that Youth A was receiving a consequence for the incident and Youth A told Staff 2
that he called Staff 1 a predator. Staff 2 said that Youth A told her that Staff 1
touched him, but when Staff 2 asked Youth A when this happened, Youth A said it
was a “while ago” and didn’t remember exactly. Youth A gave a letter to the
Therapist and told the Therapist about Staff 1 touching him. Staff 2 said she sat in a
meeting with the Therapist, Supervisor and Youth A to discuss the incident and to try
and get more information from Youth A, but Youth A didn’t say when this happened.
Per Staff 2, Youth A was questioned as to why he only brought this up after
receiving a consequence. When I asked Staff 2 about whether she reported this
allegation, she said she was not there on the day it initially occurred and when she
came back, the Therapist had the letter, so Staff 2 thought the Therapist reported it. I
clarified for Staff 2 that the requirement to report is not lifted because she thought
someone else reported and also noted that it is his obligation to ensure allegations
are reported to Centralized Intake so that they may be investigated.
5

Documentation reviewed for this investigation:
 Facility Rule Violation and Disciplinary Consequence Record for Youth A,
dated 10/18/21, authored by Staff 1 and approved by the Supervisor.
‘Threatening/Bullying’ noted as the rule violation and explained ‘Youth A
disrespected staff by threatening to beat her u, was using profanity and not
following staff directives.’ consequences included verbal apology, apology
letter, 1 RTP assignment, 3 days loss of free time rec privileges and return to
level 1 Merit Privileges for 5 days.
 Written statement from Youth A, undated. Youth A confirmed during his
interview this was his statement. In the statement, the letter noted, ‘Me and
Staff 1 started arguing because I called her a predator. She touched me
before in my area where I didn’t feel comfortable.’ ‘She’s a predator how lid to
touch kids. She touched me before here on Pod B and bought me a bag of
chips not to say anything…’
 Written statements from the other youth. Youth D’s statement said that he has
not seen Staff 1 touch Youth A, but ‘I have seen other peers from another pod
get touched inappropriately.’ Youth D did not provide any further information
on this during his interview.
 Written statement from Staff 1, dated 11/23/21. Staff 1 denied the allegation.
 Highland Park Police Department Incident No: 21-002393, dated 11/23/21.
Youth A reported Staff 1 touched him 10 times in his genital area and always
in Youth A’s bedroom. Youth A did not want to provide details and did not
want to press charges. Staff 1 denied the allegations. The Facility Manager
reported he learned of the allegation a month prior. When the officer asked
why it wasn’t reported then, the FM said that the information was in the letter
Youth A wrote and it ‘“mostly" contained information about Youth A's
discipline and only briefly mentioned something about Staff 1 being a
predator.’ The FM reported that it was reported now, as Youth A told the
DHHS PREA auditor, so they needed to follow up.
 MiSACWIS Incident Report, 126780182, authored by the Director. ‘While
being interviewed by PREA Consultant on Monday, November 22, 2021,
Resident, Youth A, alleged that Youth Worker, Staff 1, touched him
inappropriately about a month ago. Until further notice, Staff 1 will not have
any contact with Youth A until the completion of an investigation. A PREA
Investigation has been initiated.
 Facility policy on Privacy and Confidentiality, Duty to Report: The policy
outlines for staff to immediately report the incident to their supervisor as well
as to report directly to Child Protective Services.
6

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications.
(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
(b) Experience to perform the duties of the position
assigned.
ANALYSIS: The facility is compliant with the rule as there is no supporting
evidence that Staff 1 touched Youth A inappropriately. Staff 1
denied this and none of the other youth recalled any
inappropriate actions by Staff 1. The report by Youth A was
vague and did not include any dates. Although he reported this
to have occurred in his bedroom, there are no cameras in the
bedrooms and because so much time had passed, there would
be no video to review.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The facility did not report the allegations of possible abuse as required.
INVESTIGATION:
During the course of this investigation, it was found that the facility did not report the
allegation of abuse to Centralized Intake as required. As previously noted in the
above interview notes, four mandated reporters, the Therapist, the Supervisor, Staff
2, and Facility Manager, failed to report Youth A’s allegation of Staff 1 touching him
inappropriately to Centralized Intake. Each reported they thought someone else
would have reported it and did not communicate with one another to ensure it was
reported.
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4131 Compliance with child protection law; development of plan
required.
The licensee shall develop and implement a written plan to
assure compliance with the child protection law, 1975 PA
238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
ANALYSIS: Four staff had knowledge of Youth A’s allegation that Staff 1
touched him inappropriately and did not report it to Centralized
Intake. The incident was eventually reported, when Youth A
mentioned it to a DHHS PREA analyst who told the Director.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2022C0207002 intake 10/05/21, CAP approved 12/21/21
The CAP for this violation must indicate that all staff,
including Therapists, Supervisors, Facility Managers,
Nurses, and Administrators, etc., are retrained on the child
protection law and their obligation to report allegations of
abuse. This violation is not specific to direct care staff.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This is due to the overlapping timeframe of the repeat violation, and
the recent approval of the previous violation CAP only eight days ago, and the
change in leadership that occurred in October 2021. This recommendation is
contingent on the facility submitting an acceptable corrective action plan for the
noted violation.
